articles.headline: Justice Dept. Reverses Course on Citizenship Question on Census, Citing Trump’s Orders
articles.snippet: The president contradicted statements by his Justice and Commerce Departments that census forms were being printed without the question and they would heed a court ruling.
articles.abstract: The president contradicted statements by his Justice and Commerce Departments that census forms were being printed without the question and they would heed a court ruling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after pledging that the 2020 census would not ask respondents about their citizenship, Justice Department officials reversed course on Wednesday and said they were hunting for a way to restore the question on orders from President Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: The Man Who’s Putting More Sex Toys on Walmart’s Shelves
articles.snippet: “I want to become the Kleenex of sex toys,” says Jamie Leventhal, whose small consumer products company was tapped by the giant retailer to create a new line.
articles.abstract: “I want to become the Kleenex of sex toys,” says Jamie Leventhal, whose small consumer products company was tapped by the giant retailer to create a new line.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Mass. — Last year, Jamie Leventhal, the chief executive of Clio, a small company that makes devices like personal hair trimmers, got a call from a buyer he knew at Walmart.

articles.headline: Washington Prepares for a July 4 Spectacle, Starring and Produced by President Trump
articles.snippet: The president has ordered the last-minute transformation of the traditional July 4 activities into what he calls “a celebration of America” and that critics call a celebration of Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The president has ordered the last-minute transformation of the traditional July 4 activities into what he calls “a celebration of America” and that critics call a celebration of Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Bradley armored vehicles rumbled into place on Wednesday in front of the Lincoln Memorial, to be joined later by two Abrams tanks parked nearby. Cranes were putting into place the scaffolding for Jumbotron screens. And workers raced to finish a red, white and blue stage where President Trump will preside over one of the most unusual Fourth of July celebrations the capital has known.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Manslaughter Charge Dropped Against Alabama Woman Who Was Shot While Pregnant
articles.snippet: The case of Marshae Jones, who was indicted over the death of the fetus she was carrying when she was shot, had stirred outrage across the country.
articles.abstract: The case of Marshae Jones, who was indicted over the death of the fetus she was carrying when she was shot, had stirred outrage across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Alabama said on Wednesday that they were dropping a manslaughter charge against a woman over the death of the fetus she was carrying when she was shot in the belly, in a case that stirred national outrage.

articles.headline: Drink a Pint, Waste Less Food
articles.snippet: A brewery in Manchester, England, has been using discarded breakfast cereal to make beer in a project intended to address the issue of waste.
articles.abstract: A brewery in Manchester, England, has been using discarded breakfast cereal to make beer in a project intended to address the issue of waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: In all his years in the beer industry, Keith McAvoy had never taken much professional interest in Coco Pops.

articles.headline: Trump’s Decision to Tap Shelton Creates Political Risk for the Fed
articles.snippet: Judy Shelton, President Trump’s nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, criticizes how the central bank sets rates — and could reignite an old controversy.
articles.abstract: Judy Shelton, President Trump’s nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, criticizes how the central bank sets rates — and could reignite an old controversy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a steamy afternoon in late May, Judy Shelton was camped out in the lobby of the Trump Hotel in Washington, holding court with reporters from her perch on a high-backed couch.

articles.headline: Southerners, Facing Big Odds, Believe in a Path Out of Poverty
articles.snippet: Moving from poverty to wealth from one generation to the next is least likely in the South, but optimism there is greatest, tinged with political views.
articles.abstract: Moving from poverty to wealth from one generation to the next is least likely in the South, but optimism there is greatest, tinged with political views.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — A widening income gap and sagging social mobility have left dents in the American dream. But the belief that anyone with enough gumption and grit can clamber to the top remains central to the nation’s self-image.

articles.headline: Beverage Companies Embrace Recycling, Until It Costs Them
articles.snippet: They have pledged to help fix U.S. recycling, but for decades the companies have fought against “bottle bills,” which result in more bottles and cans being recycled but are costly for the industry.
articles.abstract: They have pledged to help fix U.S. recycling, but for decades the companies have fought against “bottle bills,” which result in more bottles and cans being recycled but are costly for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Recycling is struggling in much of the United States, and companies like Coca-Cola say they are committed to fixing it.

articles.headline: He Enjoys American Coffee and Restaurants. Is He a Credible Negotiator for Iran?
articles.snippet: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian most closely associated with the 2015 pact, is under fire both at home and in Washington, which is weighing sanctions on him.
articles.abstract: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian most closely associated with the 2015 pact, is under fire both at home and in Washington, which is weighing sanctions on him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iranian hard-liners have long mocked their foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, as the make-believe American, after a character in a comic Iranian movie who puts on an accent, wardrobe and lifestyle to live out a fantasy of American life.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and David D. Kirkpatrick
